page.title: 10Robinson Crusoe.
page.content: In Lower Largo there is a statue on the side of a house near the coast. The figure is dressed in skins and looks out across Largo Bay.The statue is on the site of the house where "Robinson Crusoe" was born in 1676. Alexander Selkirk was the son of a cobbler and a wild and adventurous boy.His sense of adventure inspired the author Daniel Defoe to write the 'Crusoe' story.Selkirk left home and travelled widely by boat.As sailing master of the 'Cinque Ports' he argued with officers and was placed ashore on an island called Juan Fernandez. There he stayed in solitude for 4 years and 4 months until discovered by an English sea captain who returned him to England where he told his story to Defoe who immortalised him in the 'Robinson Crusoe' book.
